semantic_title: Dominant/Nondominant Side Coding for Neurological Conditions
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 6. Chapter 6: Diseases of the Nervous System > a. Dominant/nondominant side

content.full_text: Codes from category G81, Hemiplegia and hemiparesis, and subcategories G83.1, Monoplegia of lower limb, G83.2, Monoplegia of upper limb, and G83.3, Monoplegia, unspecified, identify whether the dominant or nondominant side is affected. Should the affected side be documented, but not specified as dominant or nondominant, and the classification system does not indicate a default, code selection is as follows: • For ambidextrous patients, the default should be dominant. • If the left side is affected, the default is non-dominant. • If the right side is affected, the default is dominant. (Evidence: pg no: 45, L79-L84)
content.summary: Provides default rules for determining dominant vs nondominant side when documentation specifies affected side but not dominance status (Evidence: pg no: 45, L79-L84)
key_concepts: Dominant/nondominant side identification (Evidence: pg no: 45, L79-L80)
Default assignment rules (Evidence: pg no: 45, L80-L81)
Ambidextrous patient rules (Evidence: pg no: 45, L82)
Left side default (Evidence: pg no: 45, L83)
Right side default (Evidence: pg no: 45, L84)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Codes identify dominant or nondominant side affected (Evidence: pg no: 45, L79-L80)
detailed_rules.explanation: Specific neurological condition codes distinguish between dominant and nondominant side involvement (Evidence: pg no: 45, L79-L80)

detailed_rules.rule_text: For ambidextrous patients, default should be dominant (Evidence: pg no: 45, L82)
detailed_rules.explanation: When patient is ambidextrous and dominance not specified, assume dominant side is affected (Evidence: pg no: 45, L82)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If left side affected, default is non-dominant (Evidence: pg no: 45, L83)
detailed_rules.explanation: When left side is documented as affected but dominance not specified, assume non-dominant (Evidence: pg no: 45, L83)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If right side affected, default is dominant (Evidence: pg no: 45, L84)
detailed_rules.explanation: When right side is documented as affected but dominance not specified, assume dominant (Evidence: pg no: 45, L84)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify neurological condition requiring side specification
Step 2: Check if dominance is explicitly documented
Step 3: If dominance not specified, determine affected side
Step 4: Apply default rules: ambidextrous=dominant, left=non-dominant, right=dominant
Step 5: Assign appropriate code with dominance specification

code_ranges.description: Hemiplegia and hemiparesis (Evidence: pg no: 45, L79)
code_ranges.requirement: Must specify dominant or nondominant side
usage_rules: Apply default rules when dominance not specified (Evidence: pg no: 45, L80-L84)

code_ranges.description: Monoplegia of lower limb (Evidence: pg no: 45, L79-L80)
code_ranges.requirement: Must specify dominant or nondominant side
usage_rules: Apply default rules when dominance not specified (Evidence: pg no: 45, L80-L84)

code_ranges.description: Monoplegia of upper limb (Evidence: pg no: 45, L79-L80)
code_ranges.requirement: Must specify dominant or nondominant side
usage_rules: Apply default rules when dominance not specified (Evidence: pg no: 45, L80-L84)

code_ranges.requirement: Must specify dominant or nondominant side
usage_rules: Apply default rules when dominance not specified (Evidence: pg no: 45, L80-L84)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with right-sided hemiplegia following stroke, dominance not documented
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Right hemiplegia secondary to acute stroke
step_by_step: Step 4: Apply default rule: right side = dominant
Step 5: Assign dominant side hemiplegia code

correct_coding.sequencing: Hemiplegia, unspecified affecting right dominant side
correct_coding.rationale: Right side affected defaults to dominant when dominance not specified (Evidence: pg no: 45, L84)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should use dominant (right=dominant default), not nondominant

coding_scenarios.scenario: Left-handed patient with left arm monoplegia, handedness documented but dominance not specified for affected side
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Left upper extremity monoplegia in left-handed patient
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify monoplegia of upper limb (G83.2)
Step 3: Note patient is left-handed (left is dominant)
Step 4: Since dominance not explicitly stated for condition, apply default
Step 5: Left side default = nondominant (despite patient being left-handed)

correct_coding.sequencing: Monoplegia of upper limb affecting left nondominant side
correct_coding.rationale: Default rule applies: left side = nondominant when dominance not specified for the condition (Evidence: pg no: 45, L83)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Must follow default rules, not infer from patient handedness
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Inferring dominance from patient handedness rather than applying defaults

warnings: Default rules apply only when dominance not specified in documentation (Evidence: pg no: 45, L80-L81)
Do not infer dominance from patient handedness unless explicitly documented for the condition
best_practices: Always check if dominance is explicitly documented first (Evidence: pg no: 45, L80-L81)
Apply default rules consistently (Evidence: pg no: 45, L82-L84)
common_mistakes: Not applying default rules when dominance unspecified
tips: Only use defaults when dominance not specified
clinical_context: Important for stroke and neurological condition coding
